speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.2: High School Renovation Project - The board will consider approval of funding for major facility improvements at the high school, including building four new science laboratories and repairing the athletic fields. The science lab construction is projected to cost $1,240,400 spread over four years, while athletic field repairs are included in the same package. These upgrades aim to improve STEM instruction and student access to safe extracurricular facilities.. Who would like to start?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I appreciate that we're looking into these improvements. For the record, can you confirm if those costs include a plan for incorporating environmental sustainability features within the new labs, as well as any necessary accommodations for students with disabilities in both the classrooms and on the playing fields? It'd also be great to hear an update about what input has been gathered from teachers regarding instructional design for the new spaces. Thank you!

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Jonnoalcaro asks some crucial questions. The architectural firm designing our renovations did incorporate sustainable components into their proposal; however, there wasn't specific emphasis placed upon them during discussions. We can revisit that topic once the project enters its detailed design phase. Teachers were involved throughout the planning stages, but it may be helpful to have another opportunity for additional input prior to finalizing designs. As far as accessibility goes, compliance with Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) standards remains mandatory in all parts of the project. Our chief business officer could provide more details on these topics later. Does anyone else wish to discuss anything related to this item before proceeding?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thanks, Katrina, for addressing Jonnoalcaro's thoughtful concerns. I agree that revisiting sustainable elements and gathering further teacher feedback are essential aspects to ensure our renovation aligns with our values and meets the needs of our diverse student body. In terms of phasing, has the administration considered implementing these projects concurrently to minimize disruptions to our students' learning environment, or would it be more feasible to stagger the timelines for each component? Additionally, how do we envision maintaining open communication channels with stakeholders throughout the project duration?

speaker: judyle
content: I completely concur with David's suggestions. Implementing concurrent phasing might indeed mitigate potential disruptions to our students' educational experience. However, it's equally important to weigh that against possible logistical challenges and added costs. Regarding stakeholder engagement, I propose establishing regular town hall meetings and dedicated web pages to maintain transparency and encourage ongoing community involvement throughout the project lifecycle. By doing so, we can foster trust, address emerging concerns, and guarantee our investment benefits not only the students but also the broader community.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Judy, your idea of hosting town halls and creating a centralized online platform resonates deeply with me. Open communication and transparent updates are vital to building trust among our constituents. Concurrent phasing does present pros and cons, which warrant careful consideration. Perhaps our administrative team could prepare a detailed analysis outlining the trade-offs between concurrency and staggering the timeline for each project component. This information will enable us to make informed decisions aligned with our priorities – student well-being, safety, and optimal resource allocation. Ellen, would it be possible to request such an analysis by our next meeting?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Absolutely, David. I completely agree that a thorough analysis of the phasing options would be beneficial in informing our decision-making process. I'll instruct our administrative team to prepare a comprehensive report outlining the advantages and disadvantages of concurrent versus staggered phasing, including potential impacts on students, logistics, and budget. This will allow us to make a well-informed decision that balances our priorities. I'll ensure the report is ready for review by our next meeting. Additionally, I support Judy's suggestion of regular town halls and a dedicated webpage to maintain open communication and transparency throughout the project. This will help us stay accountable to our community and ensure that their voices are heard throughout the renovation process.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Before moving forward with analysis and plans for phasing and oversight, let's briefly touch base on the scope of athletic field repairs. Could we please receive an updated overview of the current state of our athletic fields, highlighting areas where we see critical safety issues or infrastructure deficiencies requiring immediate attention? Clarifying the full extent of needed repairs will enable us to better understand the budgetary implications and prioritize accordingly.  And I wholeheartedly endorse Judy and David's push for transparency and continued community engagement throughout the project life cycle.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Kate, that's a fantastic point. Understanding the current state of our athletic fields is crucial in determining the scope of repairs and allocating resources effectively. I've asked our maintenance department to prepare a detailed assessment of the athletic fields, identifying areas with critical safety issues and infrastructure deficiencies. They'll provide a prioritized list of required repairs, which will inform our budget allocations and phasing decisions. I expect to receive the report by the end of the week and will share it with the committee ahead of our next meeting. Your endorsement of transparency and community engagement is greatly appreciated, Kate. It's essential that we keep our stakeholders informed and engaged throughout this process.

speaker: kateacuff
content: That sounds wonderful, Ellen! Having concrete data on hand will empower us to create a targeted strategy, ensuring we allocate funds wisely and tackle high-priority safety concerns first. Receiving the report beforehand allows us ample time for review, and I'm confident that our collective expertise will result in astute recommendations. Also, I believe our town halls should involve opportunities for written comments, providing avenues for quieter voices to contribute meaningfully and fostering a truly inclusive dialogue. Shall we schedule a town hall session following receipt of the athletic field assessment report? This way, we can engage directly with the public and answer their pressing questions before making key decisions.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Well said, Kate! Including written comment opportunities will undoubtedly enhance inclusivity at our town halls. Scheduling one after receiving the athletic field assessment makes sense, allowing us to respond thoughtfully to constituent queries and consider diverse perspectives while deliberating over the proposed plan. Let's solidify a date for that town hall shortly. Meanwhile, are there any other thoughts about strategies to facilitate collaboration with local organizations or residents potentially impacted by construction noise, traffic changes, or environmental concerns linked to our renovations? How best can we demonstrate respect for nearby communities and garner meaningful cooperation throughout this transformative initiative?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I appreciate Kate's focus on the athletic field assessments and Judy's emphasis on transparent communication through town halls and online platforms. For those collaborations you mentioned, Jonnoalcaro, Graham Page from facilities suggested partnering with neighboring institutions and engaging in early discussions regarding shared interests like transportation management and noise mitigation. His input may prove valuable as we navigate neighborhood relationships and responsible growth during our construction phase. Would you like him to elaborate, Jonnoalcaro?  Or perhaps our next step is setting up that town hall session once the athletic field report arrives? We should then decide whether that event should serve as an open discussion forum or include a formal presentation. What are everyone's thoughts on the format and timing of that upcoming event?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Excellent points all around, colleagues. I concur with Kate's suggestion to incorporate written comment opportunities into our town halls, ensuring every voice has a chance to be heard. Regarding local partnerships, Graham's insights will indeed be invaluable; his expertise will help us strike a balance between project needs and neighborly considerations. I recommend inviting Graham to brief us on potential partnership strategies and lessons learned from past collaborations. As for the town hall format, I suggest a hybrid approach – an initial presentation summarizing the athletic field report findings, followed by an open Q&A and discussion period. This structure will allow us to efficiently convey key information while still facilitating authentic engagement with attendees. Once we finalize the details, we can begin promoting the event across various channels, encouraging broad participation from our school community and neighbors alike.

speaker: judyle
content: I want to echo my appreciation for the thoughtful suggestions made so far, particularly Kate's emphasis on inclusivity and David's proposal for a hybrid town hall format. To build upon these ideas, I think it would be beneficial to establish clear goals and objectives for our town hall sessions, ensuring they remain focused on gathering constructive feedback and addressing community concerns. By doing so, we can create a productive atmosphere that fosters meaningful exchanges and facilitates trust-building within our stakeholder groups. Perhaps we could also explore ways to incentivize attendance, such as offering childcare services or language translation support, thereby increasing accessibility and broadening participation.

speaker: kateacuff
content: I appreciate the nuanced discussion unfolding here. It's evident that we're committed to balancing our needs with community sensitivities. David's hybrid town hall idea strikes me as an excellent compromise, combining informative content with organic interaction. Inviting Graham to share his experiences with inter-institutional collaborations will be enlightening. In terms of incentives for attending the town hall, Judy's proposals hold merit – childcare services, language support, and possibly even offering refreshments could encourage greater involvement. Furthermore, considering alternative formats, like virtual town halls, might cater to individuals who cannot attend in person due to mobility constraints or conflicting commitments. Our goal remains fostering connections with constituents, so exploring innovative methods to reach them seems worthwhile. Shall we task Ellen with coordinating logistics for both Graham's briefing and the subsequent town hall event?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Thank you, Kate. I'd be happy to take the lead on organizing both events. I'll work closely with Graham to schedule his briefing and ensure he shares his expertise on successful partnership strategies. Additionally, I'll collaborate with our communications team to promote the town hall session, incorporating the hybrid format suggested by David, and exploring options for childcare services, language support, and virtual access to increase participation. Judy, your emphasis on establishing clear goals and objectives for the town hall sessions resonates with me. I propose we develop a set of guiding principles to focus our efforts, ensuring we prioritize constructive feedback, address community concerns, and maintain transparency throughout the process. Shall I draft these principles and circulate them among the committee prior to our next meeting for review and refinement?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thanks, Ellen. Drafting guiding principles sounds sensible to me, ensuring clarity and consistency in our town hall objectives. Your coordination of Graham's briefing and the town hall event will certainly streamline our planning. I endorse including Judy's proposed incentives for boosting attendance, alongside Kate's notion of exploring alternative formats for enhanced accessibility. Before proceeding, does anyone have further thoughts on potential risks or challenges we should proactively mitigate during the town hall and renovation phases? Consideration of possible obstacles now will enable more effective contingency planning later. If no immediate concerns arise, let's proceed with Ellen's tasks, moving forward with confidence.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: No additional comments or concerns come to mind immediately. Ellen, please move ahead drafting those guiding principles, and send them out before our next meeting so we may discuss them thoroughly. Please also touch base with Graham to schedule his briefing on collaborative approaches for managing potential impacts. Finally, I think Graham will need to participate in our town hall session since his guidance on local partnerships and shared problem-solving will likely stimulate insightful conversations. With the direction clarified, shall we confirm our roles and responsibilities moving forward? Next steps seem well-defined but I just wanted to reiterate what each of us is undertaking based on today’s discussion. Then, unless something new comes up, I believe we’re ready to close. Any last-minute items needing attention before we adjourn?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Katrinasummarization is spot-on, and I agree that we've charted a clear course forward. To recap, Ellen will draft guiding principles for the town hall sessions, coordinate Graham's briefing, and oversee town hall logistics. Judy's emphasis on inclusive outreach and Kate's exploration of alternative formats will enhance our community engagement strategy. Graham's expertise will inform our partnership approaches, and Jonno's risk assessment will ensure we're proactive about potential challenges. Given the comprehensive plan outlined, I'm comfortable moving forward without any further additions at this time. Let's reconvene when Ellen's drafted the guiding principles, and we can refine them together. Well done, everyone!

speaker: judyle
content: I concur with Katrina's suggestion to confirm our roles and responsibilities moving forward, ensuring we're all on the same page. The summary provided by David accurately captures the assignments and focuses areas for each member. I'd like to add one minor note: once the guiding principles are circulated, I'll review them through the lens of equity and inclusion, guaranteeing that our town hall sessions truly reflect the voices and concerns of diverse stakeholders. With our collective understanding of the tasks ahead, I believe we're poised for success in engaging our community and driving positive change for our students and neighborhood partners.

speaker: kateacuff
content: I fully concur with the summarizations presented by Katrina and David. The collaboration displayed thus far has been heartening, and I'm optimistic about the progress we'll make. I appreciate Judy's commitment to scrutinizing the guiding principles for their equity and inclusivity implications; her perspective will undoubtedly strengthen our approach. In light of this thorough discussion, I see no reason to prolong our current meeting. Unless someone raises a previously unmentioned concern, I suggest we consider this matter concluded for now. We've established a solid foundation for our town hall initiative and renovation project oversight. As agreed, we'll regroup after reviewing Ellen's draft guidelines, allowing ample opportunity for refinements before finalizing our plans.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I completely agree with the summaries provided by Katrina, David, and Judy. Our collective efforts have indeed produced a robust plan, and I'm grateful for the thoughtful contributions from each of you. I'll expedite the drafting of the guiding principles, ensuring they incorporate our shared values of equity, transparency, and accountability. I'll distribute them to the group before our next meeting, allowing sufficient time for review and feedback. Judy, thank you for committing to assess the principles through an equity and inclusion lens – your input will be invaluable in guaranteeing our town hall sessions genuinely represent the diverse perspectives within our community. With our roles and responsibilities clearly defined, I believe we're well-positioned to succeed in our mission to engage the community, improve student learning outcomes, and drive positive change. Unless there are any last-minute remarks, I concur that we've covered all necessary ground for this meeting. Let's reconvene soon, armed with refined guiding principles, to propel our initiatives forward.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Absolutely nothing to add here. It seems that we've reached consensus regarding our individual roles, collective responsibilities, and specific action items. My thanks go out to Ellen for diligently capturing key points and assigning duties as per our discussions. Kate, your call for expediency feels wise given how far along we've progressed already. A brief pause for reflection doesn't hurt either. So long as nobody else sees the need to speak, I am content with declaring this particular gathering officially closed. Thank you, friends!

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Consensus has been achieved then. Our committee is officially adjourned until we reconvene upon receipt of the guiding principles draft prepared by Ellen. Remember to carefully review these principles prior to our next meeting, whereupon we can engage in a fruitful exchange of ideas leading to their eventual ratification. Many thanks again for your participation and valuable insights throughout this process. Everyone stay safe, and we look forward to resuming our work shortly. Meeting adjourned!

speaker: davidoberg
content: Well said, Katrina! I wholeheartedly endorse the sentiments expressed around the table. Our collective effort has yielded a comprehensive plan, and I'm thrilled to see our committee functioning cohesively towards a common goal. Before we disperse, I'd like to extend my gratitude to each of you for your dedication to enhancing our school community. Your tireless efforts will undoubtedly benefit our students, teachers, and surrounding neighborhoods. Stay energized, and I look forward to reconvening soon with fresh perspectives and a renewed sense of purpose. Until next time, farewell!

speaker: judyle
content: In closing, I would like to express my appreciation for the diligent work accomplished during this meeting. By acknowledging our shared goals and recognizing the importance of inclusivity, equity, and community engagement, we have forged a strong foundation for our joint endeavors. I echo David's sentiment, thanking each participant for their unwavering commitment to creating positive change within our educational environment. Together, we will strive to foster growth, address pressing needs, and ultimately enrich the lives of our students and community members. Farewell for now, and let us look forward to continued progress and cooperation in the days ahead.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote publicly.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.2: Should the board approve funding of $1,240,400 over four years for new science labs, along with athletic field repairs at the high school?.  Jonnoalcaro, can you please start us off?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: yes

speaker: grahampaige
content: Jonnoalcaro votes yes.  Thank you, Jonnoalcaro.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Callsen, your turn.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: yes

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Callsen votes yes.  Thank you, Ms. Callsen.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Mr. Oberg, your turn.

speaker: davidoberg
content: yes

speaker: grahampaige
content: Mr. Oberg votes yes.  Thank you, Mr. Oberg.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Le, your turn.

speaker: judyle
content: yes

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Le votes yes.  Thank you, Ms. Le.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Acuff, your turn.

speaker: kateacuff
content: yes

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Acuff votes yes.  Thank you, Ms. Acuff.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Osborne, your turn.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: yes

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Osborne votes yes.  Thank you, Ms. Osborne.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Now it's my turn to vote.

speaker: grahampaige
content: yes. Motion passes. The meeting is adjourned. We stand adjourned. Thank you very much. Goodnight. And thank you to those who were watching online tonight. And also want to wish everyone an enjoyable Thanksgiving break. This meeting has been recorded and will be available later tomorrow morning on the county website.  If there are any questions, please don't hesitate to reach out to our office. Thanks again, and happy holidays. Thank you. Happy holiday season. Everyone okay? Okay. Goodbye. Have a good night. It was great seeing everyone here. Bye now. Goodbye. Have a nice evening. Thank you. Have a great Thanksgiving. You too. Yes, sir. You're welcome. And Merry Christmas.
